newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mild earthquakes shake Mexico City, Managua.
newsitem.headline: Mild earthquakes shake Mexico City, Managua.

text.p: A mild earthquake shook Mexico City on Thursday about two hours after another mild quake rocked parts of Nicaragua, but there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries.

The Mexico quake occurred just after 11 a.m. local time (noon EDT) (1600 GMT), said John Minsch, a geologist at the U.S. National Earthquake Information Service in Golden, Colorado. He did not have a strength measurement.
He said the Mexico quake followed one measured at 5.7 on the open-ended Richter scale in Nicaragua, which hit some 40 miles (64 km) south-southwest of the city of Chinandega on the Pacific Coast.
U.S. President Bill Clinton had been on a state visit to Mexico until Wednesday night, but was in Costa Rica on Thursday, which neighbours Nicaragua.
The Nicaragua quake took place at 8:01 local time (10:01 a.m. EDT) (1401 GMT) and was centred in the Pacific Ocean some 96 miles (155 km) east of Managua.
During this century, two large earthquakes in 1931 and 1972 nearly destroyed Managua.

On Sept. 19-20, 1985, twin earthquakes devastated Mexico City and nearby states. They measured 8.1 and 7.3 on the Richter scale. The death toll was more than 8,000, and damage was estimated at $5 billion.
